description: From Middle English miserere, a borrowing from Latin miserēre (“have pity”), first word of the 51st Psalm (50th in the older Greek and Latin numbering), translating Ancient Greek ἐλέησον (eléēson) and Biblical Hebrew חָנֵּנִי‎ (ḥānnēnî), inflected form of חָנַן‎ (ḥānan, “have mercy”).

entries.meaning: An expression of lamentation or complaint.
A medieval dagger, used for the mercy stroke to a wounded foe; misericord.

(architecture) A small projecting boss or bracket on the underside of the hinged seat of a church stall, intended to give some support to a standing worshipper when the seat is turned up; a misericord.
